study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a moderate to high intensity aerobic and strength exercise training programme could slow cognitive impairment in people with mild to moderate dementia.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise programme did not slow cognitive impairment, with a small but statistically significant increase in cognitive decline in the exercise group. Physical fitness improved, but no benefits were observed in secondary outcomes like activities of daily living or quality of life.
population_specificity: 494 people with mild to moderate dementia (average age 77, 61% male).
effective_dosage: Not specified (moderate to high intensity aerobic and strength exercise, supervised sessions).
study_duration: 4 months of supervised exercise, with follow-up at 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and potential efficacy of adding email counseling to a pedometer-based walking intervention in a primary care setting.
results_summary: Both intervention groups significantly increased daily step counts, with the pedometer-plus-email group showing a larger (though not statistically significant) increase. Combined analysis revealed significant reductions in body mass, waist circumference, and systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Physically inactive patients, predominantly overweight and obese, recruited from general practices.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer-based intervention with or without email counseling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of the FIRM rehabilitation program for improving walking ability in elderly individuals after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to assess FIRM's impact on walking ability (Koval score) at multiple follow-up intervals, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Elderly patients post-hip fracture surgery.
study_duration: 2 weeks (with follow-ups at 1 and 3 weeks, 3, 6, and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the short-term effects of customized arch support insoles on symptomatic flexible flatfoot in children using the ICF framework.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant improvements in pain/comfort, physical health, stair ascent time, upper extremity and physical function, and transfer and basic mobility compared to the control group. These improvements align with the ICF framework's domains of body functions and structures and activity and participation.
population_specificity: 52 children with symptomatic flexible flatfoot.
effective_dosage: Not specified (customized arch support insoles worn for 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of home-based telerehabilitation (including walking training) with traditional centre-based pulmonary rehabilitation in people with chronic respiratory disease.
results_summary: The study found that walking training, as part of pulmonary rehabilitation, was effective in improving dyspnea scores, 6-min walk distance, endurance cycle time, physical activity, and quality of life, with comparable outcomes between home-based and centre-based programs.
population_specificity: People with chronic respiratory disease.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of aerobic exercise (including walking training) twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and potential effects of an 8-week walking-based exercise intervention on improving sleep in people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a pilot trial to assess recruitment rates, retention, and adherence, but no results on the efficacy of walking for sleep improvement in RA patients are provided yet. The abstract indicates the study will generate preliminary data for a future larger trial.
population_specificity: People with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
effective_dosage: 28 walking sessions over 8 weeks (2-5 times/week), with 1 supervised session per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the validity of a shoe-type IMU system compared to a 3D motion capture system for analyzing gait in patients with Parkinson's disease during continuous treadmill walking.
results_summary: The shoe-type IMU system showed excellent agreement with the motion capture system for measuring linear accelerations and spatiotemporal gait parameters (cadence, step length, and step time) in patients with Parkinson's disease. The system was deemed reliable for objective gait analysis in clinical settings.
population_specificity: Seventeen participants with Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on measurement validation, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the real-world effectiveness of adding Trimetazidine (TMZ) to antianginal treatment in reducing angina symptoms and improving walking distance, particularly across different durations of stable angina.
results_summary: Adding TMZ significantly reduced the frequency of angina attacks and short-acting nitrate use, improved angina-free walking distance, and enhanced patient well-being across all groups, regardless of angina duration. Results were rapid (within 2 weeks) and sustained over 6 months.
population_specificity: 741 patients with stable angina pectoris, grouped by disease duration (from <1 year to >9 years).
effective_dosage: TMZ modified release 35 mg twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the safety and potential efficacy of RT-100, a gene therapy delivered via intracoronary injection, in reducing heart failure hospitalizations and improving ejection fraction in patients with HFrEF.
results_summary: The phase 2 study demonstrated the safety of RT-100 and suggested potential efficacy at higher doses, including a possible reduction in congestive heart failure admissions one year post-randomization. The phase 3 FLOURISH study aims to further evaluate these outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with HFrEF (heart failure with reduced ejection fraction).
effective_dosage: One-time intracoronary administration of RT-100 (10^11 viral particles).
study_duration: One-time intervention with follow-up over one year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of physical activity interventions, including walking, in improving psychological well-being among working adults in office settings.
results_summary: Walking interventions, along with yoga and exercise, were found to improve well-being in workplace settings compared to no intervention, though the evidence was mixed due to methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Working adults in office-based workplace settings (total participants: 1326).
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in the abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining action observation and motor imagery (AO + MI) of locomotor tasks could improve rehabilitation outcomes after hip replacement surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention, only mentioning the initial screening and randomization of participants.
population_specificity: 21 participants who underwent hip replacement surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise differentially affects gait performance and neural activation in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) who experience freezing of gait (freezers) versus those who do not (non-freezers).
results_summary: The study found that all participants had significantly slower and shorter backward walking velocity and stride length compared to forward walking. The exercise intervention did not improve gait or neural activation during motor imagery, but freezers showed lower BOLD signal in key motor and sensory regions during backward gait imagery compared to non-freezers.
population_specificity: 37 participants with Parkinson's disease (both freezers and non-freezers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the bioavailability of generic versus branded dalfampridine (10 mg extended-release tablets) in healthy adults under fed conditions.
results_summary: The study compared the pharmacokinetic parameters of generic and branded dalfampridine in a crossover design, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy or safety outcomes regarding walking improvements.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the concept of Locomotive Syndrome (LoS), its assessment methods, prevalence, and management, and to differentiate it from frailty and sarcopenia.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes the concept of LoS, its assessment methods, prevalence, and relevance to musculoskeletal problems, but does not provide specific results on the efficacy or safety of walking as an intervention.
population_specificity: Individuals at high risk of musculoskeletal ambulation disability (LoS or pre-LoS) in an aging society.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and other precapillary forms of PH (pcPH) and explore its clinical correlates, including the role of 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found that HRQoL was moderately impaired in patients with PAH and pcPH, with worse outcomes in those with higher disease severity (WHO FC III/IV). The 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) was identified as a significant clinical correlate of HRQoL.
population_specificity: Portuguese patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and other precapillary forms of PH (pcPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if chronic essential amino acid (EAA) supplementation, aerobic exercise (AE) training, or their combination could improve muscle mass and function by stimulating muscle protein synthesis in older adults.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise training increased walking speed and aerobic fitness, and when combined with EAA supplementation, it also increased muscle strength and EAA-stimulated muscle protein synthesis, though without improvements in muscle mass.
population_specificity: Nonfrail, independent, healthy older adults (age 72 ± 1 years) who were low-active and nondiabetic.
effective_dosage: 15 g EAA daily, supervised AE training 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how plantar blood flow responds to accumulated pressure stimulus during walking in diabetic patients with different peak plantar pressures, to assess diabetic foot ulcer risk.
results_summary: Walking significantly decreased blood flow in the first metatarsal head in both high and low peak plantar pressure groups, but no significant differences were found between the groups. The study suggested that accumulated mechanical stimulus, beyond peak pressure and pressure-time integral, should be considered in ulcer risk assessment.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients (11 with high peak plantar pressure, 8 with low peak plantar pressure).
effective_dosage: Accumulated stimulus of 73,000 kPa·s on the first metatarsal head during natural walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and feasibility of early mobility, including walking, in ICU patients with external ventricular drains (EVDs).
results_summary: The study found that early mobility, including walking, was feasible and safely tolerated in patients with EVDs, with 54% of encounters involving walking with assistance or better and only 2.2% adverse events recorded.
population_specificity: ICU patients with external ventricular drains (EVDs) who were awake, following commands, and met specific hemodynamic and intracranial pressure criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify demographic and clinical moderators of the effect of an internet-delivered intervention (exercise, education, and pain coping skills training) on pain and physical function in people with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that employed participants and those with higher baseline self-efficacy experienced greater pain reduction at 3 months with the intervention. No significant differences were observed across other demographic or clinical factors.
population_specificity: People with knee osteoarthritis (n=148).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional status at ICU discharge between patients undergoing a progressive mobilization protocol (including walking) and those receiving conventional physiotherapy, while also examining physical activity levels, pulmonary and muscle function, and length of stay.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a structured approach to early mobility in ICU patients, with walking as a key component, but results are not yet reported as the trial is ongoing. The study aims to provide insights into the benefits of early mobility interventions in critical patients.
population_specificity: ICU patients from a single center (n=96).
effective_dosage: Protocol consists of five phases, ranging from passive therapies to walking and climbing stairs, adjusted based on patient ability and muscle strength.
study_duration: Not specified (intervention occurs during ICU stay; evaluations within 2 days of discharge).

study_goal: To determine the preliminary efficacy of a home-based behavior-change intervention for promoting exercise, walking activity, and disease self-management in individuals with dysvascular transtibial amputation.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in daily step count (1135 steps/day) compared to the control group (144 steps/day) at 12 weeks, with sustained improvements at 24 weeks. No significant changes were observed in the primary outcome (TUG test) or other physical function/disability measures between groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with dysvascular transtibial amputation (n=38).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise and/or gait training interventions on dual-task walking in people with stroke, comparing dual-task training to non-dual-task training.
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in both dual-task and single-task gait speed post-intervention, with dual-task training showing a larger effect on dual-task gait speed. However, the clinical significance remains unclear due to small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Individuals with stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of a 5-week Mokhuri treatment program (integrative nonsurgical therapy) with conventional nonsurgical treatments for symptomatic lumbar spondylolisthesis.
results_summary: The abstract describes a study protocol but does not provide results; outcomes will be assessed at multiple follow-up points up to 102 weeks post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic lumbar spondylolisthesis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Mokhuri program includes Chuna, acupuncture, and patient education; conventional treatments include pain relief drugs, epidural steroid injections, and physical therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of technology-based interventions, particularly shoe-insoles, to improve gait control and reduce injury risks associated with impaired walking.
results_summary: The study suggests that shoe-insole modifications, combined with sensor technologies, can enhance gait control by providing ankle joint support, shock absorption, improved reaction speed, and dynamic balance preservation. Real-time monitoring using in-shoe systems and GPS could further optimize gait management.
population_specificity: Individuals with gait impairments or those at risk of walking-related injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the TEADRIP method for estimating spatio-temporal gait parameters using MIMUs in a large, diverse cohort across multiple clinical centers.
results_summary: The TEADRIP method showed consistent and accurate estimation of gait parameters (e.g., stride time, stance time, step time, stride length) with mean absolute errors under 3% for temporal parameters and 2% for stride length, comparable to instrumented mat reference values. Performance was robust across different clinical centers and populations, with minor differences between healthy elderly and Parkinsonian subjects.
population_specificity: 236 patients including Parkinson’s disease patients, mildly cognitively impaired individuals, and healthy older adults from four clinical centers.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on gait measurement, not intervention).
study_duration: Not specified (single assessment during straight-line gait at normal and fast speeds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic factors for functional outcome (specifically ambulatory status) in patients with metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC).
results_summary: The study found that 69.7% of patients could walk postoperatively compared to 49.0% preoperatively, with 84.7% maintaining ambulation after treatment. Prognostic factors included ambulatory status before treatment, time of developing motor deficits, interval from symptom to surgery, and preoperative performance status.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC) (n=4897 across 25 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of acupuncture combined with hydrotherapy on physical function and inflammatory markers in type 2 diabetic patients with mild lower-extremity arterial disease (LEAD).
results_summary: The combined therapy improved leg flow conductance, physical capacities (chair-sit-and-reach, WIQ, PCS), and reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, TNF-α, malondialdehyde, SOD, glutathione), but did not affect glycemic control (fasting glucose, Hb1Ac). Benefits persisted at 6-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients with recently diagnosed, mild lower-extremity arterial disease (LEAD).
effective_dosage: 30-minute acupuncture session plus 30-minute hydrotherapy exercise every 2 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline frontal plane knee joint kinematics could predict pain relief in overweight and obese individuals with knee osteoarthritis undergoing diet, exercise, or combined interventions.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between frontal plane knee joint kinematics and pain relief across diet-only, exercise-only, or combined interventions, suggesting no differential effectiveness based on knee motion measures.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals (BMI 33.5 ± 3.7 kg/m²) with knee osteoarthritis, predominantly female (77%), aged 66 ± 6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various exercise interventions, including walking, supervised treadmill exercise, and home-based exercise, in improving walking endurance for individuals with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that supervised treadmill exercise, home-based exercise with behavioral techniques, and upper/lower extremity ergometry significantly improved walking endurance in PAD patients. The recent CMS decision to cover supervised exercise will increase access for symptomatic PAD patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Dynamic Neuro-Cognitive Imagery (DNI™) training for improving motor and nonmotor functions in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of DNI training, but it suggests that imagery training is a recommended yet underresearched approach in PD rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Twenty subjects with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stages I-III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether breaking prolonged sitting with short bouts of walking affects adipose tissue responses, in addition to its known effects on postprandial glucose and insulin concentrations.
results_summary: Breaking sitting with short walking bouts significantly reduced postprandial glucose and insulin concentrations by approximately 50% and 40%, respectively, but did not affect adipose tissue mRNA expression or secretion of selected adipokines.
population_specificity: Eleven central overweight participants (seven men and four postmenopausal women) aged 50 ± 5 years.
effective_dosage: Walking for 2 minutes every 20 minutes over 5.5 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of adventitial dexamethasone delivery as an adjunct to standard endovascular revascularization in treating femoropopliteal peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found that direct adventitial delivery of dexamethasone resulted in primary patency rates of 78.4% (ATX) and 75.5% (PTA) at 12 months, with low rates of clinically driven target lesion revascularization (10.0% ATX, 11.0% PTA) and no major adverse limb events or deaths related to the intervention.
population_specificity: 262 subjects (283 limbs) with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (Rutherford category 2 to 4) and femoropopliteal lesions ≤15 cm in length.
effective_dosage: A mixture of dexamethasone/contrast medium (80%/20%) delivered to the adventitia and perivascular tissues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the mobility of elderly patients with unstable trochanteric fractures treated with either cement-augmented or non-augmented PFNA implants, focusing on walking speed.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking speed between the two treatment groups at any follow-up point. However, the cement-augmented group had fewer reoperations due to mechanical failure or implant migration.
population_specificity: Ambulatory patients aged 75 or older with closed, unstable trochanteric fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the limitations of modeling the foot as a single rigid-body segment in gait analysis and propose alternative methods to better understand foot and ankle dynamics.
results_summary: The study found that treating the foot as a rigid body overestimates muscle-tendon power at the ankle and misrepresents foot contributions, skewing comparisons between biological and prosthetic limbs. It recommends alternative methods to improve accuracy in biomechanical gait analysis.
population_specificity: Individuals with biological feet and those with transtibial amputation using prosthetic feet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent progress in gait training after stroke, analyze limitations of current robot-assisted step training (RAST), and propose a minimal assistance strategy for improved gait rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that current RAST clinical trials have unsatisfactory results, possibly due to inadequate analysis of movement deficiencies and task specificity. The authors proposed a minimal assistance strategy focusing on hip flexion and ankle dorsiflexion during swing phase and suggested a novel device design to improve gait training.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with gait impairment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the medium-term efficacy of extracorporeal shockwave therapy for improving walking distances in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in maximum walking distance, intermittent claudication distance, and post-exertional ankle-brachial pressure indices in the active treatment group at 12 months, with no improvements in pre-exertional indices. Quality of life improved in 3 out of 19 domains, and both groups had a 26.7% re-intervention rate.
population_specificity: Patients with unilateral intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week over three weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of meditative movement (tai chi, yoga, and qigong) on improving lung function and physical activity in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that meditative movement significantly improved the 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and lung function (FEV1) in COPD patients compared to the control group, with greater benefits observed at 6 months than at 3 months.
population_specificity: COPD patients (1,176 participants across 16 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extending continuous adductor canal block (CACB) infusion from three to five days improves analgesia and quality of recovery after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that extending the infusion to five days significantly improved pain scores while walking on day five (median score of 1 vs. 3 in the control group). Secondary outcomes, including quality of recovery and mobility, were also assessed but not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (86 recruited, 78 analyzed).
effective_dosage: 0.2% ropivacaine via continuous adductor canal catheter.

study_goal: To determine whether a home-based exercise intervention using a wearable activity monitor and telephone coaching improves walking ability in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) over 9 months.
results_summary: The home-based exercise intervention did not improve walking performance compared to usual care, with no significant differences in 6-minute walk distance or secondary outcomes. The intervention worsened pain interference scores but had no effect on other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), mean age 70.2 years, 52.5% women.
effective_dosage: 4 weekly medical center visits during the first month, followed by 8 months of wearable activity monitor use and telephone coaching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-management program, including walking (assessed via the 6-minute walking test), could improve clinical status indexes like dyspnea and exercise tolerance in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in spirometry indexes but reported significant improvements in dyspnea and exercise tolerance in the intervention group compared to the control group. The self-management program, which included walking, was effective in enhancing functional status.
population_specificity: 50 COPD patients referred to a respiratory clinic.

study_goal: The researchers were examining a rare case of spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma (SSEH) that occurred during normal walking, focusing on its presentation and resolution.
results_summary: The study reported a case of SSEH in a 17-year-old female that occurred during walking, leading to severe neck pain and limb paralysis, but symptoms resolved spontaneously within 9 hours. Imaging showed near-complete dissipation of the hematoma without surgical intervention.
population_specificity: 17-year-old female with no recent trauma, infection, or drug administration.

study_goal: To compare changes in knee pain, function, and loading between a progressive walking program with or without toe-out gait modification in people with medial tibiofemoral knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both groups showed improvements in self-reported pain and function, but only the toe-out group demonstrated significant biomechanical improvements in foot progression angle and knee joint loading. No between-group differences were found in knee pain, function, or timed stair climb.
population_specificity: Individuals with medial tibiofemoral knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Progressive walking program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balance-training protocols could improve both balance and locomotion in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study compared two balance-training protocols (standing on a moving platform and traditional balance exercises) but did not provide specific results regarding their effects on locomotion in the abstract.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if postoperative improvements in walking distance (6MWD), gait quality, and functional disability (ODI) in patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) would achieve normal values and correlate with perceived functional limitations.
results_summary: The study found that ODI scores decreased (indicating reduced disability) and 6MWD increased postoperatively, with gait quality changes explaining a significant portion of ODI variance. Gait quality did not deteriorate during the 6MWT, and patients' gait parameters approached normal values by 12-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted preoperatively, at 10 weeks, and 12 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, reliability, and validity of smartphone-based digital biomarkers, including walking, for monitoring Parkinson's disease in a clinical trial setting.
results_summary: The study found that smartphone-sensor data, including time spent walking, significantly differentiated Parkinson's participants from healthy controls and correlated with clinical severity ratings. Passive monitoring detected abnormalities in walking even in participants with no clinical signs of gait disturbance.
population_specificity: 44 Parkinson's disease participants and 35 age-matched healthy controls.
study_duration: 6 months for Parkinson's participants, 45 days for healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of immersive virtual reality (IVR)-based therapy on walking competences and endurance in children with bilateral cerebral palsy-diplegia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking pattern (stride length, walking speed), endurance (6MWT), gross motor abilities (GMFM-88), and most kinematic and kinetic parameters after the IVR-based intervention. The improvements were influenced by age and cognitive abilities, suggesting IVR may enhance motor/perceptual integration beyond walking training.
population_specificity: Sixteen school-aged children (mean age 11 ± 2.4 years) with bilateral cerebral palsy-diplegia attending mainstream schools.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resistance training alone or combined with nutritional supplements and cognitive training on oxidative stress, antioxidant defense, and physical fitness in institutionalized elderly individuals.
results_summary: Resistance training (RT) and RT combined with supplementation (RTS) significantly improved physical performance. RT showed greater improvements in antioxidant defense and DNA stability, particularly in subjects over their statistical life expectancy, while supplementation might inhibit optimal cellular response to exercise.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elderly individuals (mean age 83.1 ± 6.1 years) living in Vienna.
effective_dosage: Two guided training sessions per week (specific supplement dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between the adiponectin/leptin ratio (a marker of adiposopathy) and insulin resistance/sensitivity before and after a 16-week walking program in inactive women with obesity.
results_summary: The study investigated changes in insulin resistance, insulin sensitivity, and insulin response following a 16-week walking program, but the abstract does not specify the magnitude or statistical significance of these changes.
population_specificity: 29 physically inactive pre- and postmenopausal women with obesity (BMI 29-35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ekso™ gait training (EGT) improves gait performance and fosters brain plasticity mechanisms more effectively than conventional overground gait training (OGT) in chronic stroke patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: EGT significantly improved gait performance (10m walking test), cortico-spinal excitability, sensory-motor integration, gait quality, muscle activation, and frontoparietal effective connectivity compared to OGT. The neurophysiological changes correlated strongly with clinical improvements.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with hemiparesis (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the predictive role of pulmonary artery enlargement (PAE) with other clinical and physiological markers for survival in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that PAE and age were the most powerful predictors of all-cause mortality in COPD patients with mild to moderate airflow limitation. Other factors like smoking history, BMI, and exercise capacity were also associated with survival but less predictive.
population_specificity: 188 patients with COPD, mild to moderate airflow limitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on cognitive-based interventions for improving mobility in older adults and assess their clinical effectiveness on gait performance.
results_summary: Cognitive training interventions showed a small but significant effect on complex gait (dual-task walking) but no significant effect on simple gait (normal walking). The study suggests cognitive interventions may improve mobility, particularly in challenging walking conditions requiring executive functions.
population_specificity: Older adults without major cognitive, psychiatric, neurologic, and/or sensory impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical capacity (muscle strength and walking ability) in women with fibromyalgia versus healthy controls and examine associations with age, symptom duration, activity limitations, and BMI.
results_summary: Women with fibromyalgia showed 16% lower walking ability compared to healthy controls. Walking ability was significantly associated with symptom duration, activity limitations, age, and BMI in the fibromyalgia group.
population_specificity: 118 women with fibromyalgia and 93 age- and education-level-matched healthy women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical characteristics of LAM with elevated pulmonary artery pressure and evaluate the potential efficacy of sirolimus.
results_summary: The study found that in the TRV > 2.8 m/s group, the estimated systolic PAP was significantly elevated compared to the TRV ≤ 2.8 m/s group. Linear analysis showed a correlation between SPAP and forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV1).
population_specificity: 50 LAM patients (all female, average age 38.6 ± 8.1 and 41.5 ± 8.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of two nitinol self-expanding stents for treating atherosclerotic iliac artery lesions and their impact on walking impairment in patients with peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in Walking Impairment Questionnaire scores (walking impairment, speed, distance, and stair climbing) at 30 days and 9 months, with a low major adverse event rate (1.3%) and high primary patency (95.8%).
population_specificity: Subjects with Rutherford classification peripheral arterial disease stages 2-4 and atherosclerotic common/external iliac artery lesions up to 10 cm in length and >50% stenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different types and schedules of financial incentives differentially affected the likelihood of meeting a walking goal and if perceived incentive value influenced behavior.
results_summary: Walking increased in incentive conditions compared to the control, but no differences were found between incentive types or schedules. Perceived value of the incentive was associated with meeting the walking goal but was not influenced by reinforcement type or schedule.
population_specificity: 153 participants in a between-subjects experiment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether essential amino acid (EAA) supplementation could enhance rehabilitation therapy for improving walking capacity in elderly patients after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: The study found that EAA supplementation (8 g/day) combined with rehabilitation therapy significantly improved walking capacity (measured by 6-minute walking distance) compared to rehabilitation alone or rehabilitation with placebo.
population_specificity: Elderly subjects recovering from hip fracture surgery (20 ± 11 days post-trauma).

study_goal: To assess whether tiotropium/olodaterol, with or without exercise training, improves exercise endurance time and physical activity in COPD patients participating in a self-management behavior-modification program.
results_summary: Tiotropium/olodaterol, with or without exercise training, significantly improved exercise endurance time but did not increase objective physical activity compared to behavior modification alone. It reduced activity-related dyspnea and difficulty.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
effective_dosage: Tiotropium 5 μg, tiotropium/olodaterol 5/5 μg, once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a mapping algorithm to convert the Achilles Tendon Rupture Score (ATRS) to the EQ-5D utility values for use in cost-effectiveness analyses of Achilles tendon rupture treatments.
results_summary: The study found that mapping ATRS items related to pain and walking limitations (items four, five, and six) provided the best predictor of EQ-5D scores, enabling utility value derivation for QALY calculations.
population_specificity: 100 patients (43 surgical, 44 non-surgical) with acute Achilles tendon rupture.
study_duration: Follow-up at three time points (duration not specified)

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of gait training with virtual reality (VR) on walking distance and physical fitness in individuals with Parkinson's Disease (PD).
results_summary: The VR and treadmill groups showed longer walking distances and faster gait speeds compared to the control group. VR training resulted in more intense heart rate responses during sessions, but these gains were not maintained at follow-up.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's Disease (n=37)
study_duration: Pre-intervention, post-intervention, and follow-up (30 days after intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate associations between neighborhood walkability and the incidence and persistence of childhood asthma.
results_summary: Low neighborhood walkability was associated with an increased risk of both incident asthma (hazard ratio: 1.11) and ongoing asthma (odds ratio: 1.12). Walkability improvements, such as better street connectivity, may help prevent asthma.
population_specificity: 326,383 children born between 1997-2003 in Toronto, followed until ages 8-15.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walkability assessed, not a dosage-based intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in sedentary behavior (SB) resulting from a physical activity (PA) intervention in older adults and assess the influence of sex on these changes.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in SB (-25 minutes), largely due to increased moderate- to vigorous-intensity PA (+17.3 minutes). Reductions in SB were achieved through fewer shorter sedentary bouts and varied small changes, with differences observed between sexes.
population_specificity: Inactive older adults (N = 120).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) training on ankle spasticity, balance, and walking ability in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI) at the cervical level.
results_summary: Both WBV and control groups showed significant improvements in spasticity, balance, and walking ability, but the WBV group demonstrated greater improvements in spasticity, postural sway length, Timed-Up and Go test, and 10 m-Walk Test. The study concluded that WBV may be a safe and effective intervention for improving these symptoms in cervical iSCI patients.
population_specificity: Patients with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI) at the cervical level (n=28).
effective_dosage: 20-minute sessions, twice a day, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of age, environment, and mixed reality on texting while walking (TeWW) performance.
results_summary: Indoors, both young and older adults experienced similar interference while texting and walking, but only older adults showed increased gait variability under dual-task conditions. Outdoors, TeWW led to larger age-related differences in gait variability, texting accuracy, and dual-task costs, with young adults performing better if they had higher visual scanning and cognitive flexibility. Mixed reality did not improve walking or texting performance.
population_specificity: Young adults (n=30; 27.8±4.4 years) and older adults (n=20; 68.9±3.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical features that differentiate childhood arterial ischaemic stroke (AIS) from migraine in emergency department settings.
results_summary: The study found that symptoms like weakness, seizures, ataxia, speech difficulties, or walking problems were more frequent in AIS, while vomiting, visual or sensory disturbances, and absent focal signs were more common in migraine. These differences help guide neuroimaging decisions for children presenting with brain attack symptoms.
population_specificity: Children presenting to the emergency department with migraine or arterial ischaemic stroke (AIS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the sporadic form of acute benign calf myositis and increase knowledge of this condition by systematically reviewing literature reporting sporadic cases.
results_summary: The study found that sporadic acute benign calf myositis primarily affects individuals ≤18 years old, follows a flu-like illness, presents with calf pain lasting ≤1½ weeks, and is self-limited without kidney complications. Infectious triggers included influenza viruses, Dengue, Epstein-Barr, Parainfluenza virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
population_specificity: Subjects ≤18 years of age (99% of cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the interrater and intrarater reliability of the Balance Computerized Adaptive Test (Balance CAT) in patients with chronic stroke across a range of balance functions.
results_summary: The Balance CAT demonstrated sufficient intrarater reliability (ICC .89-.91) but showed substantial random measurement error between different raters (ICC .84). The minimal detectable change (MDC) and MDC% varied between interrater and intrarater assessments.
population_specificity: Outpatients with chronic stroke (N=102) with balance functions ranging from sitting with support to independent walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) on respiratory muscle strength, exercise capacity, dyspnea, fatigue, quality of life, and daily living activities in asthmatic patients.
results_summary: The study found that IMT significantly improved respiratory muscle strength, exercise capacity (6-min walk test distance), reduced dyspnea and fatigue, and enhanced quality of life and daily living activities compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Asthmatic patients aged 18-65 years.
effective_dosage: 30 breaths twice daily at 50% maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining fast walking training with a step activity monitoring program improves real-world walking activity more effectively than either intervention alone in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study assessed improvements in steps per day, walking speed, endurance, and other outcomes, with follow-ups at 6 and 12 months, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The interventions were evaluated for efficacy and individual responsiveness.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (>6 months post-stroke) with baseline walking speed between 0.3 m/s and 1.0 m/s and average steps/day <8000.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the minimal clinically important differences (MCIDs) in walking performance measures (peak walking time and claudication onset time) for symptomatic patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) following supervised and home-based exercise programs.
results_summary: The study found that both supervised and home-based exercise programs resulted in small, moderate, and large MCID changes in walking performance, with peak walking time improvements ranging from 0.5 to 4 minutes. The anchor-based method yielded higher MCID values than the distribution-based method, suggesting clinically meaningful improvements in walking capacity for PAD patients.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mirror therapy on walking ability, balance, and lower limb motor recovery in stroke patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant improvements in walking speed, balance function, lower limb motor recovery, and ankle dorsiflexion range of motion, but no significant effects on mobility or ankle muscle spasticity.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 6 months of walking exercise on platelet function, specifically monocyte-platelet aggregates (MPAs), in sedentary older adults without significant cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The study found that a lack of regular exercise increased MPAs, which are linked to atherosclerosis, while regular walking inhibited this increase. However, walking did not significantly alter platelet responses to agonists, suggesting its cardioprotective effects may be mediated through MPAs rather than direct platelet function.
population_specificity: Sedentary older adults without significant cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether patient-specific differences in motor control, measured via muscle synergy analysis, were associated with gait improvements after treatment in children with cerebral palsy across two clinical centers with differing protocols.
results_summary: Walk-DMC (Dynamic Motor Control Index During Walking) was significantly associated with post-treatment improvements in walking speed and gait kinematics, with less impaired motor control predicting better outcomes, regardless of treatment group or center. The study supports that walk-DMC provides additional insights beyond traditional gait analysis for treatment planning.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (n=636 combined) and typically developing children (n=96 combined) from two clinical centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for inadequate bowel preparation in elderly patients, including the impact of walking less than 30 minutes during preparation.
results_summary: Walking less than 30 minutes during bowel preparation was significantly associated with inadequate bowel preparation (OR, 2.474; CI, 1.261-4.855; P = 0.008), suggesting it may be a surrogate for preparation failure.
population_specificity: Elderly Chinese outpatients (over 60 years) scheduled for elective colonoscopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively assess the effect of magnesium (Mg) supplementation on muscle fitness, including walking speed, across different populations.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in muscle fitness (including walking speed) from Mg supplementation in athletes and physically active individuals, but potential benefits were observed in elderly and alcoholic populations with Mg deficiency.
population_specificity: Athletes/physically active individuals (mean age 24.9), untrained healthy individuals (mean age 40.2), and elderly/alcoholics (mean age 62.7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the associations between self-efficacy and physical activity, function, and pain in older adults with knee OA, and to determine if self-efficacy mediates treatment effects on clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Higher self-efficacy was linked to better physical function, less knee pain, and greater physical activity. The combined diet and exercise intervention (D+E) significantly improved self-efficacy, physical function, and pain compared to diet or exercise alone.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese older adults (mean age 66 years) with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether additional physical therapy services, including walking, reduce hospital length of stay, improve health outcomes, and are safe and cost-effective for patients with acute or subacute conditions.
results_summary: The study found that additional physical therapy services, including walking, reduced hospital length of stay by approximately 3 days in subacute settings and improved patient activity and participation outcomes, with preliminary evidence suggesting cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults with acute or subacute conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy, safety, and durability of scrambler therapy (ST) for neuropathic pain in adolescents with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).
results_summary: ST significantly reduced pain and improved quality of life, including walking ability, with durable effects and no detected side effects. The improvement was statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Nine pediatric patients with cancer and CIPN.
effective_dosage: 45-minute daily sessions for 10 consecutive days (some required additional treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical application and effectiveness of robotic rehabilitation (Lokomat®) for improving walking in patients with neurological and gait deficits.
results_summary: The study found that most patients achieved their goals, training intensity increased over time, and initial walking speeds were slow but improved. The patient characteristics matched epidemiological data, with variations due to Lokomat® eligibility criteria.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological and gait deficits (cerebral palsy, stroke, spinal cord injury, traumatic brain injury, and other diagnoses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of supervised exercise therapy (SET), home-based exercise therapy (HBET), and walking advice (WA) on walking capacity, quality of life, and functional impairment in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: SET significantly improved maximal and pain-free walking distances compared to HBET and WA, with increases of approximately 120 and 210 meters after three months. HBET showed no clear benefit over WA, and no significant differences in mortality or serious adverse events were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
effective_dosage: SET and HBET programs typically consisted of three exercise sessions per week.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from six weeks to two years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the severity of motor fluctuations in Parkinson's disease patients is associated with daily walking quantity and changes in walking patterns after levodopa intake.
results_summary: The study found that motor fluctuation severity did not significantly influence daily walking time, but higher age and greater motor symptom severity were associated with reduced walking time. Walking patterns were most active between 8am and 1pm, averaging 72 minutes per day.
population_specificity: 304 Dutch Parkinson's disease patients (mild to moderate severity) from the Parkinson@Home study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and safety of aerobic training (treadmill walking) in women with metastatic breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic training was safe but not feasible for a significant proportion of patients, with 42% showing acceptable tolerability and improvements in VO₂. Intention-to-treat analyses showed no significant improvements in patient-reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Women aged 21-80 with metastatic (stage IV) breast cancer, 57% receiving chemotherapy and over 40% with ≥2 prior therapy lines.
effective_dosage: 36 supervised treadmill walking sessions delivered thrice weekly at 55%-80% of peak oxygen consumption.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied by 36 sessions delivered thrice weekly (~12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the Ankle Mimicking Prosthetic Foot 4.0 during walking at different speeds in transtibial and transfemoral amputees compared to able-bodied individuals.
results_summary: The study found that walking with the novel prosthetic device significantly increased heart rate and perceived exertion levels in amputees compared to current prostheses, particularly in transfemoral amputees. However, subjective measures highlighted the importance of the technology despite the higher effort required.
population_specificity: Six able-bodied subjects, six unilateral transtibial amputees, and six unilateral transfemoral amputees.
study_duration: 6-minute walk test at normal speed, followed by 2-minute walking tests at slow, normal, and fast speeds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trunk motion visual feedback (VFB) during treadmill walking improves over-ground balance in older adults with self-reported balance problems.
results_summary: The experimental group using trunk motion VFB showed significant improvements in dynamic balance (BESTest and mini-BESTest), while the control group did not. Individuals with more profound sensory impairments benefited more from the intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 75.8 years) with self-reported balance difficulties or a history of falling.
effective_dosage: Treadmill walking 3 times per week for 4 weeks in 2-minute bouts separated by seated rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the immediate and long-term effects of a 12-week supervised group exercise program on habitual walking speed and other health outcomes in older women with osteoporosis and a history of vertebral fracture.
results_summary: The study found that a 12-week multicomponent exercise program, including resistance and balance training, was designed to improve habitual walking speed, physical fitness, fear of falling, and quality of life in the target population, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Women aged 65 years or older with osteoporosis and a history of vertebral fracture.
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week multicomponent exercise program, including resistance and balance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of the sacral marker method against the gold-standard segmental analysis method for determining the center of mass (COM) during level and sloped walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the sacral marker method and segmental analysis for COM displacement, velocity, or acceleration in the fore-aft and vertical directions, but significant differences were observed in the medial-lateral direction. This suggests the sacral marker method may not be fully reliable for all COM kinematic measurements.
population_specificity: Ten healthy young subjects (age = 24.0 ± 4.5 yr, height = 174.5 ± 5.9 cm, weight = 66.9 ± 9.4 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if wearable sensors could detect instability (caution or near-falls) during walking and other movements in people with and without Parkinson's, compared to video analysis.
results_summary: Wearable sensors showed moderate agreement (74%) with video analysis in detecting stability, with higher sensitivity for stable movements (85%) but lower sensitivity for cautious/unstable movements (46%). Caution and instability were observed in 30% of performances, suggesting wearable sensors can detect subtle instability.
population_specificity: 24 people aged 60-86, with and without Parkinson's, recruited from community groups.

study_goal: To compare the effects of botulinum toxin type A (BoNT-A) combined with intensive rehabilitation versus intensive rehabilitation alone on gait improvement in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: BoNT-A combined with intensive rehabilitation improved spasticity and walking distance (6MD) more than rehabilitation alone. Both groups showed improvements in gait speed, 6MD, and TUG scores, but group I (BoNT-A + rehab) had greater improvements in ankle spasticity and dorsiflexion ROM.
population_specificity: 19 patients with chronic stroke and spastic hemiplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between potential predictors (e.g., endothelial function, arterial pulse waveform analysis) of clinical outcomes after peripheral artery percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in walking distance after PTA, transient improvement in ankle-brachial index (ABI) and flow-mediated dilatation (FMD), but no significant change in arterial pulse waveform analysis (aPWA) indices or reactive-hyperaemia index (RHI). Patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI) and other risk factors had poorer clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: 72 individuals with PAD (mean age 66.3 ± 7.2, 79.1% males), including 42.8% with CLI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robot-assisted gait training versus conventional overground physiotherapy for improving locomotion in non-ambulatory stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between robot-assisted and conventional gait training in improving walking ability, with both groups showing significant within-group improvements. The results suggest that robot-assisted training is not superior to conventional methods for early stroke rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Seventy-four subacute patients with first-ever ischemic stroke.
effective_dosage: Forty 2-hour sessions (including 45 minutes of basic training and 45 minutes of add-on training), 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare hip fracture risk in nursing home residents with and without multiple sclerosis (MS) and identify risk factors for hip fracture in those with MS.
results_summary: The study found that nursing home residents with MS had a lower incidence of hip fractures compared to matched controls without MS, likely due to higher functional dependence. Risk factors for hip fractures in MS residents included wandering and anxiolytic exposure in independent residents, and pneumonia and antidepressant use in dependent residents.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents with and without multiple sclerosis (MS), matched by age, sex, and race.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and effects of whole body vibration (WBV) on walking speed, endurance, pain, sleep quality, fatigue, leg strength, and muscle cramping in polio survivors with/without post-polio syndrome (PPS).
results_summary: Participants starting with higher intensity WBV showed improved walking speed and reduced pain severity, but no significant changes were observed with low intensity WBV or in other outcome measures. The study concluded WBV appears safe for this population.
population_specificity: Polio survivors with/without post-polio syndrome (PPS)
effective_dosage: Low intensity (amplitude 4.53 mm, g force 2.21) and higher intensity (amplitude 8.82 mm, g force 2.76), starting with ten 1-min vibration bouts/session, increasing to 20 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of different designs of ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) and compare their effects on gait parameters in individuals with hemiplegic stroke.
results_summary: All types of AFOs improved ankle kinematics in the first rocker and swing phases but had no significant effect on knee kinematics in the swing phase, hip kinematics, or third rocker function. Articulated passive AFOs showed better effects on some gait aspects compared to non-articulated passive AFOs, though more research is needed.
population_specificity: Individuals with hemiplegic stroke
study_duration: Mostly immediate or short-term effects (except two trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a Vibro-medical insole on pressure and vibration sensation in diabetic patients with mild-to-moderate peripheral neuropathy during walking.
results_summary: The Vibro-medical insole significantly improved pressure sensation at key foot areas (heel, first and fifth metatarsophalangeal heads, and hallux) and vibration sensation at the big toe (with a 256 Hz tuning fork) after 30 minutes of walking. No significant improvement was observed with a 128 Hz tuning fork.
population_specificity: 20 diabetic patients with mild-to-moderate peripheral neuropathy.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of walking with the Vibro-medical insole.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between six-minute walk distance and long-term outcomes (pulmonary arterial hypertension-related death/hospitalization and all-cause death) in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
results_summary: Patients walking >400 m at Month 6 had a significantly reduced risk of pulmonary arterial hypertension-related death/hospitalization (HR 0.48) and all-cause death. Higher baseline and Month 6 walk distances (by quartile) were also associated with lower risk, but changes in walk distance were not predictive of outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walk distance assessed, not a dosage).
study_duration: Follow-up to Month 6 and long-term outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 2-year clinical outcomes and cost-benefit analysis of a paclitaxel-resveratrol-coated balloon compared to plain old balloon angioplasty for treating femoropopliteal lesions in patients with peripheral artery occlusive disease.
results_summary: The drug-coated balloon (DCB) group showed significantly lower target lesion revascularization rates (19.1% vs. 40.6%), higher patency rates (72.3% vs. 48.4%), and greater walking distance improvement (172±103m vs. 52±136m) compared to the POBA group, along with cost savings of €1111.97 per patient.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic peripheral artery occlusive disease in femoropopliteal lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of the spinal tap test on walking and other motor abilities in patients with iNPH and to determine relationships among these outcome measures.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking time (p = 0.048) and turning steps (p = 0.001) after the spinal tap test, indicating enhanced motor performance. The relationship among outcome measures suggested similar ability levels across different activities.
population_specificity: 27 patients with clinical symptoms of idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH).
study_duration: Assessments were performed before and 24 hours after the spinal tap.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify associations between objectively measured physical activity (including walking capacity) and cognitive function in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found positive associations between moderate to vigorous physical activity and walking capacity with memory performance, but no significant associations with light physical activity or usual gait speed.
population_specificity: 130 patients (age 67 ± 8 years) with symptomatic peripheral artery disease, recruited at a tertiary vascular disease center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of bone marrow mononuclear cells (BM-MNC) autotransplantation and ECEPCs in treating critical limb ischemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found that BM-MNC autotransplantation was effective in CLI patients and demonstrated comparable therapeutic efficacy between BM-MNC and ECEPCs.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of siponimod in slowing disability progression in patients with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS).
results_summary: Siponimod reduced the risk of 3-month confirmed disability progression by 21% compared to placebo, with a safety profile similar to other S1P modulators, though adverse events were more frequent in the siponimod group.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-60 with SPMS and an Expanded Disability Status Scale score of 3.0-6.5.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate the impact of pulmonary hypertension on outcomes following MitraClip therapy, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in 6-minute walking distance among groups with varying systolic pulmonary artery pressure levels, but it did not focus on Walking as an intervention or outcome.
population_specificity: 643 patients in the TRAMI registry with varying levels of systolic pulmonary artery pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare energy utilization between prolonged sitting, sitting interrupted with regular walking breaks, and sitting combined with continuous walking.
results_summary: Short frequent walking breaks resulted in greater accumulation of elevated post-physical activity energy utilization compared to a single continuous bout, though total energy utilization was similar. Combining both activity patterns enhanced energy utilization more than either alone, potentially benefiting long-term weight management.
population_specificity: 36 adults (11 males, BMI 24.1 ± 4.6)
effective_dosage: 2-min walking every 30 min (RAB), 30-min continuous walking (SIT + PA), or both (RAB + PA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether metformin was associated with reduced muscle pain (specifically cramps and leg/calve pain while walking) in patients taking statins.
results_summary: The study found that patients taking both statins and metformin reported fewer muscle cramps (35% vs. 42%) and less leg/calve pain while walking (40% vs. 47%) compared to those taking statins alone. Multivariable regression showed a 22% reduction in odds for muscle cramps and a 29% reduction for leg/calve pain while walking.
population_specificity: Patients from the ACCORD trial sub-study who were taking statins (n=445) or both statins and metformin (n=869) at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-operative training programs (SAPP or SAPP + PERT) could improve gait mechanics in male athletes after ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: Neither training program significantly improved gait mechanics in the short-term, but gait asymmetries mostly resolved by 2 years post-operation regardless of intervention.
population_specificity: 40 male athletes (age 23 ± 7 years) after primary ACL reconstruction.
study_duration: Tested at three time points: pre-training, post-training (after 10 sessions), and 2 years post-operation.

study_goal: To investigate the relationship between the subjective impact of fatigue and objective walking capacity as well as subjective walking ability in MS patients.
results_summary: The physical impact of fatigue is weakly related to objective walking capacity, while general, physical, cognitive, and psychosocial fatigue impact are weakly to moderately related to subjective walking ability in MS patients.
population_specificity: Ambulatory MS patients (n=189, age: 47.6±10.5 years; gender: 115/74 women/men; EDSS: 4.1±1.8 [range: 0-6.5]).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effect of a lifestyle intervention to increase daily physical activity in older women through utilitarian walking and use of public transportation.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly more walking trips per week (9 vs. 4) and active transportation minutes per week (643.5 vs. 49.5) at 3 months, with sustained benefits in walking trips at 6 months (9 vs. 2).
population_specificity: Inactive older women with a mean age of 64.1 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationships between physical activity, self-efficacy, and multiple sclerosis symptoms, and whether MS symptoms moderate the self-efficacy-PA relationship.
results_summary: Self-efficacy was positively associated with physical activity, while depression and walking impact negatively correlated with self-efficacy. Anxiety moderated the self-efficacy-PA relationship, with stronger effects at lower anxiety levels.
population_specificity: 59 physically inactive individuals with a definite diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of Nordic walking and modified Sinaki exercises, alone or combined, on bone density, mobility, and fall risk in elderly women with osteoporosis.
results_summary: Nordic walking (group 3) significantly improved locomotor activity, while the combination of Nordic walking and Sinaki exercises (group 4) showed the best results, including reduced fall risk and improved rib cage mobility. Bone density improved across all groups, including the control.
population_specificity: 91 women aged 65-98 years living in residential care facilities, with osteoporosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration implied by intervention length).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether integrating dynamic weight shifting into treadmill training improves locomotor function in humans with spinal cord injury compared to treadmill-only training.
results_summary: Robotic training showed greater improvement in 6-minute walking distance compared to treadmill-only training, though walking speed improvements were not significantly different. Participants in the robotic group exhibited a 15% improvement in walking speed versus 2% in the treadmill-only group.
population_specificity: Humans with spinal cord injury (n=16)
study_duration: 6 weeks of training, with follow-up assessments at 8 weeks post-training

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on gait-related function in patients with acute/subacute stroke.
results_summary: RAGT was found to improve walking ability in subacute stroke patients, with significant enhancements in gait speed, functional ambulatory category, and Rivermead mobility index compared to conventional physical therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with acute/subacute stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical outcomes and functional improvements of ankle arthroplasty versus arthrodesis in patients with end-stage ankle arthritis over a three-year period.
results_summary: Both surgical groups showed reduced pain, improved survey scores, and increased walking speed at one year, with results maintained over three years. Arthrodesis patients exhibited altered gait mechanics (e.g., reduced ankle RoM, increased hip RoM), while arthroplasty patients improved ankle RoM and cadence without restoring gait to unaffected limb levels.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage ankle arthritis (arthroplasty n=27, arthrodesis n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Re-Step system's ability to measure stride-time parameters and assess its reliability and feasibility in gait analysis.
results_summary: The study found a strong correlation (r = 0.971) between stride times measured by the treadmill and the Re-Step system, high inter-rater reliability (ICC = 1.000 for stride time), and a significant increase (0.68%) in stride-time variability during perturbed walks, indicating the system's validity and utility in gait research.
population_specificity: Fifteen healthy adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 35% hydrogen peroxide and 37% carbamide peroxide in nonvital bleaching ("walking bleaching") on periodontal markers (RANK-L and IL-1β) and tooth color variation.
results_summary: Both bleaching agents significantly increased RANK-L and IL-1β levels compared to baseline, with no differences between the two agents. Both therapies effectively changed tooth color.
population_specificity: 50 volunteers with discolored nonvital teeth and good endodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: Four sessions of bleaching gel application (35% hydrogen peroxide or 37% carbamide peroxide).
study_duration: Four sessions, with follow-up at one week and one month post-bleaching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a motorized aquatic treadmill exercise program improves isometric strength, cardiorespiratory fitness, arterial stiffness, motor function, balance, functional outcomes, and quality of life in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The aquatic therapy group showed significant improvements in peak oxygen consumption, maximal isometric strength of knee muscles, motor function, balance, daily living activities, and quality of life compared to the land-based exercise group. However, improvements in isometric strength were also noted in both groups.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maslinic acid (MA) combined with whole-body vibration training (WBVT) improves knee and muscle function in elderly women with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Participants with severe knee OA who took MA with WBVT showed significant improvements in muscle function (isokinetic extension peak torque) and knee function (pain on walking and range of motion), while the placebo group saw few positive results.
population_specificity: 26 females aged 65-85 years with knee osteoarthritis (K-L grade ≥ 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical features of subacute stroke patients that predict better responsiveness to robotic walking therapy compared to conventional gait training.
results_summary: Robotic walking therapy improved the probability of achieving autonomous walking, particularly in patients with higher trunk control test scores at admission. Conventional therapy showed better outcomes for patients with higher Barthel Index scores and shorter time since stroke, while robotic therapy was more effective for those with better trunk control.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke inpatients (n=100)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of autologous cell-based therapy (CBT) compared to non-cell-based therapy (NCT) in patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found that CBT showed similar all-cause mortality rates to NCT, with improvements in ulcer healing, ankle-brachial index (ABI), transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcO2), pain-free walking capacity, and collateral vessel formation. BM-MNC and m-PBSC were more effective than NCT in reducing amputation rates and improving limb perfusion parameters, while BM-MSC improved perfusion parameters but not amputation rates.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing protein intake beyond the RDA (0.8 g/kg/d) to 1.3 g/kg/d improves lean body mass, muscle performance, physical function, and well-being in older men with physical function limitations.
results_summary: The study found that protein intake exceeding the RDA did not increase lean body mass, muscle performance, physical function, or well-being measures, nor did it enhance the anabolic response to testosterone. Fat mass decreased in participants given higher protein but remained unchanged in those given the RDA.
population_specificity: Functionally limited men aged 65 years or older with usual protein intake ≤0.83 g/kg/d.
effective_dosage: 0.8 g/kg/d or 1.3 g/kg/d of protein, with or without testosterone enanthate (100 mg weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a minimal-dose task-oriented circuit gait training intervention, including caregiver involvement, for improving locomotor recovery and walking competency in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: The task-oriented circuit gait training group showed significant improvements in walking distance (6MinWT), gait speeds, balance (BBS), and mobility (TUG) compared to strength training and control groups, with sustained benefits at follow-up. The results were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Persons post-stroke (mean age 50 years, 72 women, mean 9.5 weeks post-stroke) in the South African public health sector.
effective_dosage: Six 1-hour sessions of task-oriented circuit gait training over 12 weeks.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of cerebellar transcranial direct current stimulation combined with transcutaneous spinal direct current stimulation on robot-assisted gait training in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Significant differences in the 6-minute walk test were noted between groups immediately post-treatment but were not maintained at 2- or 4-week follow-ups. Cathodal cerebellar stimulation combined with spinal stimulation may enhance robot-assisted gait training effects in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Chronic brain stroke patients with walking impairment
effective_dosage: Ten 20-minute sessions (five days a week for two weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcome of early surgical management for a spinal gunshot injury with partial neurological deficit and CSF leak, including the patient's ability to walk post-surgery.
results_summary: The patient underwent surgical intervention, including bullet fragment removal and spinal stabilization, and was able to walk with a walking frame by day 7. At 1-year follow-up, there was a satisfactory radiological result but a remaining partial motor deficit in both ankles.
population_specificity: A 30-year-old male with a spinal gunshot injury resulting in paraparesis and CSF leak.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short- and mid-term effects of proprioceptive and balance training on functionality and balance in patients undergoing total knee and hip replacement.
results_summary: The study found moderate to high significant effects of balance and proprioceptive training on self-reported functionality and balance after total knee replacement, with effects maintained at mid-term for balance alone. No benefits were observed for preoperative training in total hip arthroplasty.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee and hip replacement (567 participants across 8 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether feedback on activity levels via a smart watch could increase daily physical activity and improve functional outcomes in stroke survivors during inpatient rehabilitation.
