results_summary: The study protocol outlines plans to measure changes in daily activity, mobility, independence in personal care, and quality of life, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors within 4 months post-stroke, previously able to walk independently, receiving inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Feedback provided at five time periods throughout the working day (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Up to 3 weeks or until discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of pedometer-based walking interventions in maintaining increased physical activity levels at 3-4 years post-intervention.
results_summary: Both trials showed sustained increases in daily step counts and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) at 3-4 years, with statistically significant improvements compared to controls, particularly in the PACE-UP trial. The PACE-Lift trial also demonstrated significant MVPA improvements, though step count increases were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45-75 years (PACE-UP) and 60-75 years (PACE-Lift) from UK primary care practices.
effective_dosage: 12-week walking program (pedometer, handbooks, PA diaries) delivered postally or with nurse support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of angioplasty compared to non-surgical therapy or no therapy for improving walking distances and quality of life in people with mild to moderate intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Angioplasty showed short-term benefits in improving ankle brachial pressure indices and walking distances in one trial, but these effects were not sustained long-term. In another trial, an exercise program for controls showed comparable improvements to angioplasty.
population_specificity: Adults (average age 62) with mild to moderate intermittent claudication (20 women, 78 men).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 6 months to 6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 24-month impact of primary stenting versus best medical treatment alone on health-related quality of life, walking ability, and physiological outcomes in patients with intermittent claudication due to superficial femoral artery disease.
results_summary: Primary stenting significantly improved health-related quality of life (SF-36 and EQ5D scores), ankle-brachial index, and walking distance compared to best medical treatment alone, with durable benefits observed over 24 months. Both groups showed improvements, but the stent group demonstrated superior outcomes in physical function, pain, and general health domains.
population_specificity: Patients with stable intermittent claudication caused by superficial femoral artery disease (n=100, randomized to stent or control groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention was stenting procedure vs. medical treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of functional electrical stimulation (FES) on stroke patients with foot drop and identify factors distinguishing responders from nonresponders.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking speed (10mWT), gait steps, mobility (TUG), and endurance (6MWT) among responders. Gender, number of interventions, and active ankle dorsiflexion ROM were key predictors of response to FES.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (aged >20 years) with foot drop, enrolled from hospitals between 2013-2015.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated (enrollment period: January 2013 to September 2015).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of endovascular revascularization on functional performance and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication (IC) compared to no treatment, conservative therapy, or combination therapies.
results_summary: Endovascular revascularization showed moderate to large short-term improvements in walking distances but no clear long-term benefits compared to no treatment or supervised exercise alone. Combining revascularization with supervised exercise or pharmacotherapy (cilostazol) yielded greater functional and quality-of-life improvements than conservative therapy alone.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC), a symptomatic form of peripheral arterial disease.
effective_dosage: Cilostazol 100 mg twice daily (in pharmacotherapy arms).
study_duration: Varied by study; long-term follow-up included up to two years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of an intramuscular glucocorticoid injection compared to a placebo for reducing hip pain in patients with hip osteoarthritis, particularly during walking.
results_summary: The study found that the intramuscular glucocorticoid injection significantly reduced hip pain at rest by 2 weeks and during walking by 4 weeks, with effects persisting up to 12 weeks. WOMAC pain scores also improved from 6 to 12 weeks post-injection.
population_specificity: Patients with painful hip osteoarthritis (n=106).
effective_dosage: 40 mg triamcinolone acetate, single intramuscular injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of functional gait training on walking ability in children and young adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Functional gait training showed clinically important benefits for walking speed, with a moderate positive effect over standard physical therapy. There was also weaker but consistent evidence for improvements in walking endurance and gait-related gross motor function.
population_specificity: Children and young adults with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of ulinastatin on inflammatory response and cognitive function after hip arthroplasty in elderly patients with femoral neck fracture.
results_summary: Ulinastatin reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory markers, improved neurological function, and promoted postoperative recovery, including earlier off-bed walking and discharge times compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with femoral neck fracture undergoing hip arthroplasty (n=80).
study_duration: Intervention effects measured up to 48 hours post-intervention, with follow-up until discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the preferences and attitudes of adults with substance use disorders (SUDs) toward physical activity, including walking, to improve adherence and reduce attrition in PA interventions.
results_summary: The study found that adults with SUDs were interested in walking, among other activities, and preferred engaging in these activities alone or in small groups at familiar locations like treatment clinics.
population_specificity: Adults with substance use disorders (SUDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of skipped multifocal extensive spinal tuberculosis (TB) involving the whole spine and its impact on the patient's ability to walk.
results_summary: The study found that spinal TB caused significant difficulty in walking and sleeping for the patient, with atypical presentations and imaging features. The patient was treated with anti-TB medication for 12 months, but no specific outcomes related to walking were reported.
population_specificity: 33-year-old Chinese male with skipped multifocal extensive spinal TB.
effective_dosage: Not specified (anti-TB treatment regimen details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of progressive resistance training on functional capacity, including walking capacity, in end-stage renal disease patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking capacity (6-minute walk test) between the progressive resistance training group and the control group. Other measures like leg strength and flexibility improved, but walking performance remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 52 hemodialysis patients (aged 55.7 ± 14.03 years)
effective_dosage: Two sets of 15-20 repetitions, thrice a week

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to assess the feasibility and safety of an alternative approach for left ventricular endocardial pacing via interventricular septal puncture in patients for whom standard cardiac resynchronization therapy was not possible.
results_summary: The procedure was successful in all patients with no serious complications, and clinical outcomes improved in a majority of patients, including increased LV ejection fraction and 6-minute walking distance. However, some adverse events like stroke and transient ischemic attacks were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure who either had failed transvenous LV lead placement or were nonresponders to CRT (mean age 67 ± 12, 80% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of endovascular treatment modalities (angioplasty vs. atherectomy) for symptomatic obstructions of the common femoral artery (CFA).
results_summary: Atherectomy showed significantly better 4-year primary patency compared to angioplasty, particularly in bifurcated lesions or claudicant patients, though no superiority was found in diabetic patients regarding patency or walking distance improvement. In-hospital costs were higher for atherectomy.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic CFA lesions (81.6% with claudication, 78.9% with stenosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors affecting hip moment impulse during gait in healthy adults and patients with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Several factors, including ankle push-off, body-weight unloading, and specific footwear, were found to modify hip moment impulses during gait, though effects on hip osteoarthritis progression remain unassessed.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (no patients with hip osteoarthritis were included).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of a single-session treadmill-based stance-slip perturbation program in preventing slip-related falls during overground walking among young adults.
results_summary: The training group showed a lower fall rate (28.6%) compared to controls (55.0%) and demonstrated better compensatory step control and dynamic stability before recovery touchdown. However, the training did not significantly alter gait pattern modification after an unexpected slip.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults
effective_dosage: Eight slips in a single session

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in cognitive function after a 12-week exercise intervention involving walking and other activities in adults with Down syndrome.
results_summary: Participants showed improvement in memory performance after the intervention, with statistically significant results for one memory variable (p=0.048) and a trend for another (p=0.069). The study suggests increased exercise, including walking, may positively impact cognitive functions.
population_specificity: Adults with Down syndrome (27 participants, aged 27.9 ± 7.1 years, 40.7% female).
effective_dosage: 30-minute group exercise sessions 1 or 2 times per week (averaging 26.6 ± 3.0 min/week or 57.7 ± 15.3 min/week, respectively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and safety of a locomotor training program using an overground robotic exoskeleton for individuals with complete motor spinal cord injury (SCI), focusing on recruitment, attendance, drop-out rates, walking performance, learnability, and safety.
results_summary: The study found that the training program was feasible with high attendance (97.9%) and low drop-out rates (7.1%), showing significant improvements in standing time, walking time, and step count. However, some participants experienced upper extremity pain or stiffness, and one sustained bilateral calcaneal fractures, indicating safety concerns.
population_specificity: Individuals with complete motor spinal cord injury (SCI) reliant on wheelchairs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether active video game training achieves comparable physiological and clinical effects to traditional exercise training (e.g., treadmill or cycling) in patients with chronic respiratory diseases.
results_summary: Active video game training resulted in comparable peak heart rates and dyspnea levels to traditional exercise, but there was insufficient evidence to confirm improvements in exercise capacity (e.g., 6-min walk test or treadmill endurance). The quality of evidence was low due to study heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic respiratory diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 3-week inpatient pulmonary rehabilitation program on quality of life and clinical outcomes in patients with sarcoidosis, and to identify subgroups that particularly benefit from the intervention.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance, quality of life (SGRQ), dyspnea, fatigue, anxiety, depression, and generic QoL (SF-36) after the rehabilitation program. The standardized response means indicated moderate to large effect sizes for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with sarcoidosis (average age 49.1 ± 9.7 years, 47% female, average vital capacity 3.5 ± 1.0 L).

study_goal: The researchers compared clinical and radiological outcomes, complications, and survival rates between two acetabular revision systems (trabecular metal and Burch-Schneider cages) for severe acetabular defects.
results_summary: The trabecular metal (TM) group showed higher satisfaction and HHS scores, required fewer walking aids, and had no implant ruptures compared to the Burch-Schneider (BS) group. No differences in complication rates were observed, but BS implants had higher failure instances.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing acetabular revision surgery for severe defects (AAOS types II, III, and IV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of adding a mobile application (EVIDENT 3) to traditional weight loss strategies, including evaluating changes in walking behavior.
results_summary: The study will measure changes in walking (steps/day) as a secondary outcome, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract. The intervention combines technology with traditional counseling to promote healthier lifestyles.
population_specificity: 700 sedentary adults aged 20-65 with a BMI of 27.5-40 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of decoding walking from brain activity in stroke survivors during robot-assisted gait rehabilitation using an EEG-based brain-machine interface.
results_summary: The study found improvements in walking distance and speed in chronic stroke patients after 4 weeks of training with the exoskeleton, correlating with increased offline decoding accuracy of gait kinematics. The Kalman decoder showed improved accuracy over time, suggesting enhanced neural representation for gait and feasibility for monitoring or controlling rehabilitative exoskeletons.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with hemiparesis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of running and brisk walking on physical capacity and alcohol consumption in patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD).
results_summary: The study found that running and brisk walking had an effect on drinking habits in AUD patients, but no additional benefit was observed compared to the control group. A drop in training frequency may have reduced the intervention's effectiveness.
population_specificity: 105 patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD).
effective_dosage: 30-45 minutes of running or brisk walking twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous pulmonary artery stenting and balloon angioplasty in treating silicosis-induced pulmonary artery stenosis and severe pulmonary hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that stent implantation and balloon dilatation significantly improved pulmonary artery caliber, clinical symptoms, and 6-minute walk distance in the patient. However, long-term outcomes were not sufficiently evaluated due to short follow-up.
population_specificity: A 52-year-old male stonemason with silicosis-induced pulmonary artery stenosis and severe pulmonary hypertension.
study_duration: Half a month of progressive dyspnea prior to intervention; follow-up duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 16-week corrective exercise continuum (CEC) program on 3-D joint angles of the lower limbs in children with genu varus during walking.
results_summary: The CEC program significantly reduced excessive foot and knee internal rotations and hip external rotation during walking in children with genu varus, with notable improvements in joint kinematics for both dominant and non-dominant limbs.
population_specificity: 28 male children with genu varus, aged 9-14 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the influence of a motor ability rehabilitation program on spatial-temporal gait parameters in Huntington's Disease (HD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that a three-week motor ability rehabilitation program improved walking speed and cycle length in HD patients, as measured by a three-dimensional gait analysis system.
population_specificity: 30 patients (17 women and 13 men) with Huntington's Disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether individualized exercise, including progressive walking and resistance training, could improve bone metabolism in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Exercise did not improve any bone biomarkers, and compliance with resistance training was sub-optimal (44.4%). The study concluded that exercise was feasible and well tolerated but had no significant effect on bone metabolism.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors
effective_dosage: Progressive walking and resistance training (specific dosage not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare balance control and subjective balance impressions in patients with CIDP, non-inflammatory polyneuropathy, and healthy controls during stance and gait tasks.
results_summary: Both patient groups showed greater trunk sway and reduced gait speed compared to healthy controls, with CIDP patients lacking the compensatory reduction in trunk sway seen in non-inflammatory PNP patients, suggesting a higher fall risk.
population_specificity: 11 CIDP patients (mean age 61.1, 8 male), 10 non-inflammatory PNP patients (mean age 68.5, all male), and 18 age- and gender-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: To assess the effects of PR-fampridine on cognitive functioning, fatigue, and depression in patients with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: PR-fampridine significantly improved cognitive measures (alertness, psychomotor speed, verbal fluency), reduced fatigue (physical, cognitive, total), and alleviated depressive symptoms in PwMS, with effects persisting over 2 years.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: To summarize evidence regarding exercise therapy, specifically supervised treadmill and home-based walking interventions, for improving walking ability in people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Supervised treadmill exercise significantly improved treadmill walking performance (180 m increase in maximal walking distance, 128 m in pain-free distance). Home-based walking with behavioral techniques also improved walking ability, sometimes more than supervised exercise. Upper and lower extremity ergometry also enhanced walking endurance.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Supervised treadmill exercise: 36 sessions over 12 weeks; home-based walking: frequency not specified.
study_duration: 12 weeks for supervised treadmill exercise; home-based intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy of smartphone accelerometer applications and a consumer activity wristband compared to a research accelerometer for step detection during walking, while assessing the impact of phone position on accuracy.
results_summary: The iPhone SE and Garmin Vivofit 2 showed high accuracy (MAPE <3) for step counting across different walking speeds and conditions, while the Samsung Galaxy and hip-worn ActiGraph were accurate only at higher speeds. The wrist-worn ActiGraph had poor accuracy (MAPE 17-47) in all conditions. Phone position did not affect step detection accuracy.
population_specificity: 20 volunteers from two age groups (18-25 years and 45-70 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of walking behavior change interventions, particularly those based on theoretical models, in increasing walking activity.
results_summary: The review found mixed evidence on the effectiveness of walking interventions, with some studies showing positive effects and others showing partial or no effects. Theoretically underpinned interventions, especially those using the Transtheoretical Model, showed some positive outcomes, but using multiple theories in a single intervention appeared less effective.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from reviewed studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of sirolimus in patients with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that long-term use of sirolimus was safe in LAM patients, with improvements in pulmonary function and other clinical parameters, but did not assess Walking.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with definite or probable sporadic LAM based on European Respiratory Society criteria.
study_duration: Median follow-up was 2.5 years (not specific to Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a "points-based" physical activity approach on body composition in inactive, overweight, or obese women.
results_summary: The "points-based" approach led to significant weight loss, reduced waist circumference, and trends in fat mass reduction, with increased light activity and decreased sedentary time. Body composition remained unchanged in the structured exercise group.
population_specificity: Inactive women who were overweight or obese.
effective_dosage: 30 "PA points" per week (specific activities not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to correlate physical activity level, functional capacity (including walking performance), and psychological state with quality of life in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical activity level, walking distance (>500 meters), and sitting-rising test performance (>20 repetitions) by the end of chemotherapy. Walking <300 meters at baseline was identified as a risk factor for low quality of life at week 16.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (n=121) undergoing chemotherapy with palliative or curative intent.
study_duration: Evaluated at week 0 (baseline), week 8, and end of chemotherapy (timing not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of multicomponent physical exercise programs in improving or maintaining gait ability (measured by walking speed and TUG tests) in older long-term nursing home residents.
results_summary: Multicomponent physical exercise programs were found to be effective in improving or maintaining gait ability in older LTNH residents, though study heterogeneity prevented definitive conclusions. The review highlights the need for more evidence to support these programs.
population_specificity: Older long-term nursing home residents.
effective_dosage: Exercise sessions ranged from 30 minutes to 1 hour, with intensity from 40% to 60-70% RM.
study_duration: Interventions lasted from four weeks to 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate if cystic fibrosis patients with end-stage pulmonary disease could tolerate LUM/IVA treatment and if it led to clinical stabilization, particularly in walking capacity (6-MWD).
results_summary: The study found a median increase of 33 meters in the 6-minute walking distance (6-MWD), though the result was not statistically significant (p = 0.6086). Clinical stabilization was observed, with reduced acute exacerbation rates and improved lung function parameters.
population_specificity: Phe508del homozygous cystic fibrosis patients with end-stage pulmonary disease (FEV1 <40% predicted or listed for lung transplantation).
effective_dosage: LUM/IVA initiated at a low dose and increased stepwise (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: 6-month follow-up for 10 patients (full trial duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the esthetic perception, psychosocial impacts, and clinical effectiveness of non-vital teeth bleaching using two different peroxide agents via the walking bleach technique.
results_summary: Both hydrogen peroxide and carbamide peroxide were highly effective in maintaining stable color change at 6 months, with significant improvements in esthetic perception and psychosocial factors that remained stable over time.
population_specificity: Patients with non-vital teeth undergoing bleaching treatment.
effective_dosage: 35% hydrogen peroxide (G1) and 37% carbamide peroxide (G2), administered in four sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate effect of scalp acupuncture on walking patterns in patients with subacute intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) using 3D gait analysis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in spatiotemporal parameters (step length, velocity, cadence, and double-limb support) and kinematic parameters (decreased peak pelvic anterior tilt angle and increased hip extension angle) in the treatment group after scalp acupuncture, while the control group showed no changes. No significant differences were observed in step width or other kinematic parameters.
population_specificity: 30 patients with subacute ICH who could walk independently.
effective_dosage: Acupuncture manipulation repeated three times with a 5-minute interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of tiotropium/olodaterol (at two dosages) versus placebo on endurance time during cycling and walking tests in patients with COPD.
results_summary: Tiotropium/olodaterol 5/5 µg significantly improved cycling endurance time after 12 weeks, while both dosages showed a strong trend toward improving walking endurance time, though statistical significance was narrowly missed.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify differences in hip and pelvic biomechanics during walking and squatting in patients with femoroacetabular impingement syndrome (FAIS) compared to controls and evaluate the effects of interventions on these biomechanics.
results_summary: Patients with FAIS walked with reduced peak hip extension angle, peak internal rotation angle, and external rotation joint torque compared to controls. The review found small to moderate between-group differences but noted limited and low-quality data on intervention effects.
population_specificity: Patients with femoroacetabular impingement syndrome (FAIS) and asymptomatic controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a 6-month exercise intervention (primarily brisk walking) on lower limb lymphedema prevalence in ovarian cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effect of walking on lymphedema prevalence, with both exercise and control groups showing a decrease in lymphedema prevalence over 6 months, though the difference between groups was not statistically significant. Body mass index was identified as a significant predictor of lymphedema.
population_specificity: Physically inactive ovarian cancer survivors (n = 95).
effective_dosage: Primarily brisk walking (specific frequency/duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify kinematic and kinetic abnormalities in service members with foot injuries (talus, calcaneus, and/or navicular fractures) using gait analysis and relate these to functional outcomes.
results_summary: Service members with TCN fractures showed significant differences in gait parameters, including lower walking speed, reduced ankle joint range of motion, and poorer functional scores (LEFS and CHAMP) compared to healthy controls. Correlations were found between functional outcomes and gait characteristics, suggesting altered gait impacts physical functioning.
population_specificity: Dutch military service members with combat-related foot injuries (talus, calcaneus, and/or navicular fractures) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and effects of combining aerobic exercise (lower limb cycling) with upper limb task-specific training to improve motor function in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The combined intervention was feasible and perceived as beneficial, with both participants showing modest improvements in upper limb motor function (ARAT and WMFT scores) and aerobic fitness.
population_specificity: Two female stroke survivors—one in subacute recovery (3 months post-stroke) and one in chronic recovery (14 years post-stroke).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of lower limb cycling followed by 30 minutes of upper limb task-specific training, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait patterns between unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA) patients and healthy controls during level walking to assess functional recovery post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in vertical ground reaction force or sagittal plane kinematics between UKA patients and healthy controls, but UKA patients had slower walking speed, lower cadence, and shorter stride length, indicating incomplete restoration of normal gait.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the current state-of-the-art computational methods for estimating muscle forces during walking, compare different approaches, and assess their applicability in clinical gait analysis.
results_summary: The study found broad agreement between different modeling approaches regarding muscle activation during walking but noted considerable variability in force patterns and magnitudes. Limited validation makes it difficult to determine if any approach provides consistently better estimates.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals during walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize knowledge from clinical studies using wearable sensors to monitor walking and other activities in epilepsy, Parkinson's disease, and stroke.
results_summary: Wearables were used to study walking and physical activity in stroke patients, primarily in laboratory and free-living environments. The study found that wearables could provide useful clinical information, but their utility for clinical decision-making remains to be established.
population_specificity: Patients with epilepsy, Parkinson's disease, and stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of different bypass graft types (e.g., autologous vein, PTFE, Dacron) on improving walking distance and limb salvage in patients with femoro-popliteal arterial stenosis or occlusion.
results_summary: Autologous vein grafts showed superior primary patency compared to prosthetic grafts for above-knee bypasses at 60 months, while Dacron demonstrated better secondary patency over PTFE. Below-knee bypass data were inconclusive due to limited evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with femoro-popliteal ischaemia (rest pain, tissue loss, or severe claudication).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 6 months to 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and preliminary clinical efficacy of intra-articular knee implantation of autologous bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) involving the knee.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effects from MSC administration, with improvements in WOMAC, VAS, pain-free walking distance, and standing time, though benefits were not sustained beyond 12 months. The MSC group also showed reduced use of methotrexate and prednisolone.
population_specificity: RA patients with knee involvement (n=30, 15 MSC group, 15 placebo).
effective_dosage: 40 million autologous bone marrow-derived MSCs per joint (single administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Internet-based exercise and supervised group exercise on glycaemic control, physical activity, and quality of life in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both supervised group-based and Internet-based exercise significantly improved glycaemic control, waist circumference, and quality of life compared to the control group. Group B showed improvements in fasting blood glucose and hip circumference, while Group C improved total cholesterol, walking distance, and step count.
population_specificity: 65 patients with type 2 diabetes (47 women, 18 men).
effective_dosage: Supervised group exercise three days per week; Internet-based exercise following the same program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of considering broad differential diagnoses for foot drop and the value of complete neurological examination in diagnosing rare causes like Chiari malformation type-1.
results_summary: The study found that a 6-year-old girl with foot drop had Chiari malformation type-1 with holocord syrinx, emphasizing the need for prompt diagnosis and neurosurgical intervention to improve prognosis.
population_specificity: A 6-year-old girl with foot drop and neurological deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of crossover feet (XF) and traditional energy storing feet (ESF) on health outcomes in people with transtibial amputation.
results_summary: XF improved most community-based outcomes, including mobility, fatigue, balance confidence, activity restrictions, and functional satisfaction, and most participants (89%) preferred XF over ESF. XF also resulted in longer sound side steps compared to ESF.
population_specificity: People with transtibial amputation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify accurate measures to predict future falls in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) patients and assess the prevalence and clinical profile of falls in this population.
results_summary: The study found that P13 cervical VEMP latency, N10 ocular VEMP latency, and P37 SEP latency were the most accurate predictors of future falls in MS patients, outperforming clinical measures like EDSS, T25FW, ABC, FESI, and MSWS12 scores. Among 113 patients, 72% experienced one or more falls during the one-year follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) of any subtype attending Neurology OPD, meeting revised 2010 McDonald criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and long-term effects of real-time, visual biofeedback on weight-bearing during rehabilitation after total hip arthroplasty (THA) in elderly patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in peak load during the early postoperative phase and maintained higher peak load at twelve weeks compared to the control group. The intervention group also exhibited longer walking distances and reduced use of walking aids at follow-up.
population_specificity: Elderly patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty (THA).
study_duration: During hospitalization and at twelve weeks follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prowling (walking with bent knee attitude) combined with proprioceptive training could reduce knee hyperextension and improve gait parameters in hemiparetic patients compared to routine physiotherapy.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in knee hyperextension, dorsiflexion range, and spatio-temporal gait parameters (measured by WGS) compared to the control group. While within-group analysis revealed significant improvements in time taken to cover distance, between-group differences were not significant.
population_specificity: Ambulatory hemiparetic patients (32 subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physical capacities underlying Timed 'Up and Go' (TUG) performance in community-dwelling older women.
results_summary: TUG performance was significantly associated with upper and lower limb muscle strength, balance, lower limb muscle power, aerobic capacity, and mobility. The contribution of physical capabilities to TUG performance varied by quartile, with lower quartiles showing greater dependence on lower limb muscle strength and higher quartiles showing increased reliance on other physical capabilities like power and balance.
population_specificity: 468 apparently healthy, community-dwelling older women (mean age: 65.8 ± 6.0 years) independent in daily living activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional recovery and quality of life between amputees and patients who underwent limb salvage after severe lower-limb trauma.
results_summary: The study found that amputation resulted in significantly better functional outcomes (e.g., walking distance, standing, physical activity) and overall quality of life compared to limb salvage, though there was no difference in return to work or psychological acceptance.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 18 with severe open lower-limb fractures (Gustilo IIIb or IIIc) treated at trauma centers in Marseille, France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neural and neuromuscular mechanisms controlling gait and movement, their changes post-stroke, and implications for rehabilitation interventions.
results_summary: The study discusses cortical control of gait, muscle synergies, and their alterations following stroke, highlighting potential applications in gait rehabilitation and the use of walking aids. It identifies gaps requiring further research.
population_specificity: Individuals post-stroke and general gait mechanisms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, walking performance, and satisfaction of amputees using the Meridium microprocessor-controlled prosthetic foot during routine fittings.
results_summary: Users reported improvements in walking on various terrains (level ground, uneven ground, ramps) and perceived enhanced safety and stability. Overall satisfaction was moderate (50%), with 40% preferring Meridium over previous prosthetics, particularly transfemoral amputees with specific characteristics.
population_specificity: Amputees (70 users) with varying amputation levels, ages, and mobility grades.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intensive lifestyle modification (including brisk walking) with or without liraglutide versus sleeve gastrectomy on BMI reduction and cardiometabolic risk factors in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that intensive lifestyle modification, including 30 minutes of brisk walking daily and at least 3 hours of aerobic exercise weekly, led to a 14% BMI reduction. Walking was part of a broader intervention that also included dietary changes, making its isolated effects unclear.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic patients eligible for bariatric surgery recruited from a weight-loss clinic at an Italian university hospital.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of brisk walking daily and at least 3 hours of aerobic exercise weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions designed to increase active school transport (AST) among children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that 13 out of 30 interventions increased AST, with most reporting "trivial-to-small" positive effect sizes. However, study quality was generally weak, and overall evidence quality was rated as low due to methodological limitations.
population_specificity: School-aged children and adolescents.
study_duration: Varies by intervention (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare 2-year outcomes of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) patients treated with surgery versus those under follow-up observation after a 6-week physical therapy regimen involving walking and other exercises.
results_summary: At 2 years, outcomes (except for physical function on the ZCQ subscale) did not differ significantly between surgery and non-surgery groups. Physical therapy initially improved symptom severity and physical function in the observation group, with sustained or improved outcomes over time.
population_specificity: Patients with neurogenic claudication, radiologically-confirmed central LSS affecting both legs, and refractory symptoms to pharmacotherapy for over 3 months.
effective_dosage: Body weight-supported treadmill walking once a week (frequency specified; duration per session not detailed).
study_duration: 6 weeks of physical therapy, with 2-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of placenta-derived mesenchymal stem cells (PDMSCs) hydrogel in treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) and improving wound healing.
results_summary: The PDMSCs hydrogel treatment led to almost complete healing of the foot ulcer, preserved walking function, and no complications or recurrence over 6 months. The study suggests PDMSCs hydrogel may offer a new DFU treatment approach.
population_specificity: A 57-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus and a Wagner classification III diabetic foot ulcer.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (follow-up period was 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of high-pressure intermittent limb compression (HPILC) in improving walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: HPILC was associated with a significant increase in absolute claudication distance (ACD) compared to controls, with a mean difference of 125 meters. The treatment was deemed effective and noninvasive for managing intermittent claudication.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (290 subjects total, 172 receiving HPILC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare adjusted mortality, walking ability, and return home outcomes after hip fracture surgery between Canada and the USA.
results_summary: US subjects had higher adjusted mortality than Canadians at 30 days, 60 days, and up to 3 years post-surgery. No differences were found in walking ability or return home outcomes between the two countries.
population_specificity: 2016 subjects aged 50+ with hip fractures, cardiovascular disease/risk factors, and hemoglobin <100 g/L post-surgery (76% female, average age 82).
study_duration: Data collected up to 60 days post-surgery, mortality tracked for a median of 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with a decline in self-rated health (SRH) in older patients after an emergency department visit, including the use of walking devices.
results_summary: The study found that using a walking device was an independent predictor of decline in SRH (OR 1.70). Patients with functional decline showed a steeper decline in SRH compared to those without functional decline.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥70 years) who visited the emergency department in the Netherlands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-intensity treadmill training combined with self-management education improves physical activity, walking ability, and other health outcomes in stroke survivors compared to usual physiotherapy.
results_summary: The study will compare outcomes between high-intensity treadmill training and usual physiotherapy, measuring effects on walking ability, cardiorespiratory fitness, self-efficacy, and quality of life at 8 and 26 weeks. Results are pending as the abstract describes a planned trial.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors undergoing rehabilitation who can walk independently.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes, three times a week for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of isolated intracranial Rosai-Dorfman disease (RDD) mimicking petroclival meningioma and discuss diagnostic and treatment challenges.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative diagnosis of petroclival RDD is challenging, and while surgical resection is effective, total resection is not highly recommended due to potential surgical defects. The patient recovered well with subtotal resection and gamma-knife treatment.
population_specificity: A 14-year-old girl with dizziness, headache, and walking instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of nine nonoperative regimens, including various walking-related therapies (OT, BWSTT, RAGT+OT, BWSOT), for treating spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: RAGT+OT and BWSOT showed the best efficacy for SCI patients in terms of lower extremity motor score (LEMS) and walking index (WISCI). Venlafaxine XR and GM-1 ganglioside demonstrated adequate safety profiles.
population_specificity: Spinal cord injury (SCI) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a commercial computerized cognitive training program, both alone and preceded by a 15-minute brisk walk, on cognitive function in older adults.
results_summary: The study proposed a proof-of-concept RCT to explore whether CCT programs, alone or combined with walking, could promote healthy cognitive aging, with results pending at trial completion and 1-year follow-up.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65-85 years old.
effective_dosage: 15-minute brisk walk before cognitive training (Ex-FBT group).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of exercise training on gait parameters and energy cost of walking in patients with Alzheimer's disease compared to standard cognitive treatment.
results_summary: Exercise training significantly improved the energy cost of walking in patients with Alzheimer's disease, but had negligible effects on other gait parameters. Cognitive treatment showed no detectable effect on gait parameters or energy cost of walking.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease (Mini-Mental State Examination 22±5).
effective_dosage: 90 minutes of aerobic and strength training per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of regular activity breaks (2 min of walking every 30 min) versus prolonged sitting on appetite in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that regular activity breaks increased energy expenditure but suggested potential compensatory eating behavior, though appetite effects were not conclusively detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 36 healthy adults with an average BMI of 23.9 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Tissue Doppler Imaging parameters in children with pulmonary hypertension and assess their association with functional class and Brain-Natriuretic Peptide levels, including 6-minute walking tests as part of the evaluation.
results_summary: The study found that Tissue Doppler Imaging parameters were significantly impaired in children with pulmonary hypertension compared to healthy controls. The 6-minute walking test was used as part of the functional assessment, but specific results related to walking performance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children with pulmonary hypertension (34 patients) and healthy controls (43 individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of decompression with interlaminar stabilization (D+ILS) versus decompression alone (DA) for treating moderate to severe lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), particularly focusing on walking tolerance and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that D+ILS significantly improved walking distance compared to DA, with the D+ILS group showing over 5 times the improvement from baseline versus only 2 times for DA. Additionally, D+ILS maintained radiographic foraminal height better and reduced the need for secondary interventions and pain management.
population_specificity: 230 patients with moderate to severe LSS at 1 or 2 adjacent segments from L-3 to L-5, treated at 7 sites in Germany.
study_duration: Outcomes evaluated up to 2 years postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the beneficial effects of home-based cardiac rehabilitation, including walking, on functional capacity, quality of life, and readmission rates in patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: Patients in the home-based cardiac rehabilitation group showed significant improvements in peak oxygen uptake, 6-minute walking distance, anaerobic threshold, and quality of life, along with a reduced 90-day readmission rate.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of less than 50%.
effective_dosage: Not specified (individualized rehabilitation programs including walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 16-week moderate-intensity stepping exercise program on sleep quality and patterns among community-dwelling older adults with moderate sleep complaints.
results_summary: The study found that a 16-week group-based stepping exercise program improved sleep quality (measured by PSQI) and sleep patterns (measured by actiwatch) compared to a health education control group, with physical fitness and mood status acting as mediating variables.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with moderate sleep complaints.
effective_dosage: Three 60-minute stepping exercise sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of ADS-5102 (amantadine) extended-release capsules in improving walking impairment in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: ADS-5102 showed a 16.6% placebo-adjusted improvement in walking speed (T25FW test) and a 10% improvement in TUG, but no effects on fatigue, depression, or cognition. The treatment was generally well tolerated, though some adverse events (e.g., dry mouth, constipation, insomnia) and one serious AE (suspected serotonin syndrome) were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and walking impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore associations between process evaluation measures (nurse session attendance, PA diary completion, pedometer use) and changes in physical activity outcomes (step-counts and MVPA) in a pedometer-based walking intervention.
results_summary: The study found that attending all nurse sessions, completing PA diaries, and regular pedometer use were significantly associated with increased step-counts and MVPA at 3 and 12 months, with stronger effects in the postal group at 12 months.
population_specificity: 45-75-year-old primary care patients
